abstracts.cdata!:
The  Albania Private Industry Recovery
            Project ratings are as follows:  Project outcome is
            satisfactory; sustainability is likely; institutional
            development impact is modest; Bank performance is overall
            satisfactory; and Borrower performance is overall
            satisfactory.  The lesson learned was the following:  An
            agency was established by legislation and a staff of six
            persons was employed to implement the project. As it
            eventuated, activity was not adequate to keep the staff
            fully and actively employed except in the set up period of
            training and the initial marketing. The Project Appraisal
            Document envisaged that the agency would be able to continue
            in existence after the project closed as a guarantee agency
            and provide support for cross border trade including export
            credit insurance. The project description in Part B of
            Schedule 2 envisaged the continuation of the project in the
            form of a guarantee agency unsupported by the World Bank but
            only after the project had closed at the end of January
            2003. The form of insurance or guarantees envisaged by Part
            B, such as export credit insurance, are related but more
            complex functions than providing political risk only
            guarantees. In retrospect, the objectives of the Project
            would have been better achieved by allowing the agency
            during the project implementation period to use the project
            funds on other related activities such as export credit
            insurance, subject to similar controls and restrictions as
            applied in the use of political risk insurance.

repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Private Industry Recovery Project
            : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
Before a loan will be approved under the
            Private Industry Recovery Project for Albania, it must be
            verified that the enterprise has valid municipal, city,
            canton, or state licenses to operate including the
            environmental license, and that the operations, respecting
            the nominated exports, will be in accord with the applicable
            environmental law and standards of Albania and the
            guidelines for environmental assessment listed in this
            report. A visual inspection of the premises will be
            undertaken to verify that there are no hazardous activities
            being conducted. Questions that should be answered by the
            Albanian enterprise during the application process include
            the following: Indicate that the enterprise has a specific
            inventory of the type and volume of wastes that are, or will
            be generated by the project. Specify how each type of waste
            identified will be disposed of and/or treated. Identify the
            use of any special technological or managmeent approaches to
            minimize or recycle waste or minimize emissions. Indicate
            the nature of the impacts on the natural environment, e.g.,
            water, soil, flora, and fauna. Types of projects
            unacceptable on ecological grounds will include producing
            lead-based paint; trading in wildlife or wildlife products
            prohibited under the CITES (Convention on Trade in
            Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora); introducing
            genetically altered organisms; producing, distributing, and
            selling illegal pesticides; and using drift nest in fishing.

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Private
            Industry Recovery Project is to foster a speedy revival of
            the private manufacturing sector after its collapse as a
            consequence of the recent political instability. The project
            will finance Albanian Guarantee Agency (AGA), which will
            issue guarantees to entities that finance productive
            activities in Albania. The project consists of three
            components. 1) Albania will contribute US$0.7 million as
            issued and paid-in capital for AGA. 2) Start-up costs
            (US$0.25 million) of the Albania Guarantee Agency will cover
            AGA's initial start-up costs for capital expenditures
            and administrative expenses in its first year. 3) Political
            Risks Guarantee Facility (US$20 million), managed by AGA,
            will mitigate the perceived risks that are preventing the
            private sector from having access to commercial financing
            for productive transactions or from risking their own funds
            to re-enter the market. As guarantees are issued, the funds
            will be placed in escrow with an agent bank outside Albania
            under liability until the guarantee runs off. The agent bank
            will also issue the beneficiary of the AGA an irrevocable
            standby letter of credit to ensure security.
